description



A trait which indicates whether a plant has the capacity to engage in symbioses [GO:0044403] with microorganisms [NCIT:C14329] (bacteria [NCIT:C14187], cyanobacteria [NCBITaxon:1117], and fungi [NCBITaxon:4751]) capable of nitrogen fixation [GO:0009399] and usually identified by nodulation [GO:0009877] on the plant roots [PO:0009005].
Binary variable describing whether a plant has the capacity for nitrogen fixatation, indicating it engages in symbioses with microorganisms (most commonly bacteria or cyanobacteria) that are capable of nitrogen fixation. Nitrogen fixation capacity is usually identified by nodules on the plant roots.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Plant root structures











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030028




label


Plant root structures




alternative label


root_structure




description



A trait which indicates types [NCIT:C25284] of root [PO:0009005] structures [PATO:0000141], including structures associated with mutualisms [GO:0085030] with mycorrhizae [EnvThes:20656].
Specific specialized types of root structures and root symbioses, especially symbioses with mycorrhizal fungi.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


root_structure_arbuscular_mycorrhizal Symbiosis in which the mycorrhizal fungi does penetrate the cortex cells of the plant roots and its hyphae form arbuscules and vesicles inside the plant root; endomycorrhizal, AM, VAM.
root_structure_carnivorous Plant has non-mycorrhizal carnivorous root.
root_structure_cluster_roots Non-proteoid taxa with cluster roots.
root_structure_coiling_vam Associations that spread predominantly by intracellular hyphal coils within roots.
root_structure_dauciform_root A type of cluster root found in the family Cyperaceae.
root_structure_ectomycorrhizal Symbiosis in which the mycorrhizal fungi does not penetrate the cortex cells of the plant roots.
root_structure_ericoid_mycorrhizal A form of arbuscular mycorrhizal relationship only found on plants in the order Ericales. The fungi’s hyphae penetrate the plant root but do not form arbuscules.
root_structure_fine_roots Particularly fine roots for nutrient uptake.
root_structure_haustorium A highly modified stem or root of a parasitic plant, such as mistletoe , or a specialized branch or tube originating from a hairlike filament (hypha) of a fungus. The haustorium penetrates the tissues of a host and absorbs nutrients and water.
root_structure_hemiparasitic_root Plant with a partially parasitic root.
root_structure_long_root_hairs Plant with specialised long root hairs.
root_structure_mycorrhizal Plant mycorrhizal but type not specified.
root_structure_non_mycorrhizal Plants lacking a mycorrhizal symbiont.
root_structure_orchid_mycorrhizal A mycorrhizal relationship specific to orchid taxa, and for most orchids, essential for seedlings to establish.
root_structure_parasitic_root Plant with a parasitic root.
root_structure_proteoid_root Also known as cluster roots, are plant roots that form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets and aid in nutrient upake in nutrient-poor soils; common in members of the family Proteaceae but present in other families as well.
root_structure_root_hairs Plant with specialised root hairs.
root_structure_sand-binding Persistent sheaths of sand that form around the roots of taxa in the families Restionaceae, Cyperaceae, Haemodoraceae, and Lomandraceae in western Australia. Assumed to function in nutrient uptake.
root_structure_saprophyte Plant that acquires nutrients from decaying biomass.
root_structure_subepidermal_mycorrhizal Mycorrhizae where hyphae grow in a cavity under epidermal cells. Only in the genus Thysanotus (family Laxmaniaceae).
root_structure_unknown Root structures unknown.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Plant parasitism status











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030029




label


Plant parasitism status




alternative label


parasitic




description



A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates if a plant is involved in a parasitic [ECOCORE:00000146] symbiosis [ECOCORE:00000022] where it forms haustorium [GO:0085035] on a host [GO:0018995] plant and the host plant provides all or some of its high energy [PATO:0001021] carbon [CHEBI:27594] compounds [NCIT:C43366], mineral nutrition (nutrients [CHEBI:33284]) and/or water [CHEBI:15377].
Trait indicating whether a plant forms haustoria and obtains part or all of its energy-rich carbon compounds (photosynthetic sugars), mineral nutrition and/or water directly from another plant (its host) in an interaction that does not benefit the host plant.




comments


Plants described as parasitic in the context of this trait always have haustoria, specialised organs that penetrate the host plants’s vascular bundles. The trait root_structures documents symbiotic relationships with fungi. The trait plant_energy_acquisition_strategy documents specialised strategies or specialised organs or tissues plants use to obtain carbon or mineral nutrition.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


parasitic_hemiparasitic Plant that is photosynthetic but augments its energy, mineral nutrition, and /or water supply through parasitism. This trait value does not distinguish between obligate hemiparasites, plants which require a host for at least part of their life cycle, and facultative hemiparasites, plants which can grow and reproduce without a host.
parasitic_hemiparasitic_obligate Plant that is photosynthetic but requires a host for at least part of its life cycle.
parasitic_hemiparasitic_facultative Plant that is photosynthetic and can grow and reproduce without a host but augments its energy, mineral nutrition, and /or water supply through parasitism.
parasitic_holoparasitic Plant that obtains all (or nearly all) of its energy through parasitism.
parasitic_parasitic Plant that obtains some energy, mineral nutrition and/or water through parasitism. This term is used if a dataset does not specify if a plant is a hemiparasite or a holoparasite.
parasitic_not_parasitic In the context of this trait, a plant that does not acquire energy, mineral nutrition, and/or water via haustoria connected to another plant. It can include species that form a symbiosis, including a parasitic interaction, with a fungal partner.
parasitic_root_parasitic Parasitic plant whose haustoria penetrate the root of a host plant.
parasitic_stem_parasitic Parasitic plant whose haustoria penetrate the stem of a host plant.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Plant sex type











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030060




label


Plant sex type




alternative label


sex_type




description



A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the distribution [PATO:0000060] of male [PATO:0000384], female [PATO:0000383], and hermaphroditic [PATO:0001340] flowers [PO:0009046] on one individual [EFO:0000542] and across multiple individuals in a population [PCO:0000001].
Plant sex type, indicating, for a taxon the type of flowers (male, female, and hermaphroditic) present on individual plants versus separate plants within a population.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


sex_type_androdioecious Taxa in which hermaphroditic and staminate (male) plants coexist within a population.
sex_type_andromonoecious Taxa with hermaphrodite flowers and staminate flowers (producing just male gametes) on the same plant but no pistillate (female) flowers.
sex_type_dioecious Taxa that produce male and female flowers on separate plants.
sex_type_gynodioecious Taxa in which hermaphroditic and pistillate (female) plants coexist within a population.
sex_type_gynomonoecious Taxa with hermaphrodite flowers and pistillate flowers (producing just female gametes) on the same plant but no staminate (male) flowers.
sex_type_hermaphrodite Taxa with flowers that produce both male and female gametes; bisexual.
sex_type_monoecious Taxa that have both male and female flowers on the same plant but an individual flower produces only male or female gametes.
sex_type_polygamous Taxa with both unisexual and bisexual flowers on the same plant.
sex_type_polygamodioecious Taxa where some flowers on a plant are hermaphrodite and other are pistillate (female) or staminate (male).
sex_type_polygamonoecious Taxa where some plants in a population have hermaphrodite and pistillate (female) flowers and others have hermaphrodite and staminate (male) flowers.
sex_type_trioecious Taxa where plants in a population have either hermaphroditic (bisexual) flowers, pistillate (female) flowers, or staminate (male) flowers.
sex_type_unknown Inadequate information to assign a sex type.

text:
Pollination syndrome











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030061




label


Pollination syndrome




alternative label


pollination_syndrome




description



A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on a taxon’s [NCIT:C40098] flower morphology traits [TO:0000499] that indicates the taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely pollinate [GO:0009856] a flower [PO:0009046].
For a given taxon, the biotic vectors (including explicit taxa) or abiotic mechanisms that are most likely to pollinate its flowers, based on the taxon’s flower morphology.




comments


Trait values include both very specific terms and quite general ones, reflecting the variation in detail provided across studies.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


pollination_syndrome_abiotic Floral syndrome indicates pollination occurs through wind, water, or collision of free-floating particles.
pollination_syndrome_biotic Floral syndrome suggests flowers are pollinated by a biotic agent.
pollination_syndrome_animal Floral syndrome suggests flowers are animal-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_ballistic Floral syndrome suggests pollen is launched away from the plant by explosion.
pollination_syndrome_bat Floral syndrome suggests flowers are bat-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_bee Floral syndrome suggests flowers are bee-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_beetle Floral syndrome suggests flowers are beetle-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_bird Floral syndrome suggests flowers are bird-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_butterfly Floral syndrome suggests flowers are butterfly-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_fly Floral syndrome suggests flowers are fly-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_insect Floral syndrome suggests flowers are insect-pollinated, type of insect not specified.
pollination_syndrome_mammal Floral syndrome suggests flowers are mammal-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_moth Floral syndrome suggests flowers are moth-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_thrip Floral syndrome suggests flowers are thrip-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_vertebrate Floral syndrome suggests flowers are vertebrate-pollinated (bats, birds, mammals or lizards).
pollination_syndrome_wasp Floral syndrome suggests flowers are wasp-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_water Floral syndrome suggests flowers are water-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_wind Floral syndrome suggests flowers are wind-pollinated.
pollination_syndrome_self Floral syndrome suggests flowers are primarily self-pollinating.
pollination_syndrome_pollination_rare Plants mostly reproduce through vegetative spread and flowering is rare.

text:
Pollination system











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030062




label


Pollination system




alternative label


pollination_system




description



A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on explicit field studies of pollination [GO:0009856] in the taxon’s [NCIT:C40098] native range (preferred) or else a combination of a taxon’s flower morphology traits [TO:0000499] (that suggest specific [NCIT:C38024] taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely pollinate [GO:0009856] a flower [PO:0009046]) and the pollinators actually observed visiting the taxon’s flower.
For a given taxon, the biotic vectors (including explicit taxa) or abiotic mechanisms that are most likely to pollinate its flowers, based on explicit field studies of pollination in the taxon’s native range (preferred) or else a combination of possible pollinators observed visiting a taxon’s flowers and the taxon’s flower morphology.




comments


Trait values include both very specific terms and quite general ones, reflecting the variation in detail provided across studies.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


pollination_system_abiotic Observations indicate pollination occurs through wind, water, or collision of free-floating particles.
pollination_system_biotic_unspecialised Taxa are pollinated by a biotic agent, but do not have a specialist pollinator.
pollination_system_biotic_specialised Taxa depend upon a specialist pollinator for pollen transfer.
pollination_system_animal Flowers are observed to be animal-pollinated.
pollination_system_ballistic Pollen is observed to be launched away from the plant by explosion.
pollination_system_bat Flowers are observed to be bat-pollinated.
pollination_system_bee Flowers are observed to be bee-pollinated.

pollination_system_water Flowers are observed to be water-pollinated.
pollination_system_wind Flowers are observed to be wind-pollinated.
pollination_system_self Flowers are self-pollinated.

Age of reproductive maturity











Property

https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030210




label


Age of reproductive maturity




alternative label


reproductive_maturity




description



The age [NCIT:C25150] of a plant when it is capable of sexual reproduction [GO:0000003], which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] between seed germination [GO:0009845] and when a plant is able to produce mature [PATO:0001701] seed [PO:0009010].
The age of a plant when they are able to set seed, indicating it is reproductively mature.




comments


Although reproductive maturity should be marked by the ability to set viable seed, this trait will often be scored as when plants first produce flowers, as this is easier to score. This trait is only meant to capture primary reproductive maturity, not secondary reproductive maturity following a disturbance. See a series of traits starting with fire_time_from_fire_to_flowering and fire_time_from_fire_to_fruiting for measures of secondary reproductive maturity.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Diaspore dispersal syndrome











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030211




label


Diaspore dispersal syndrome




alternative label


dispersal_syndrome




description



A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on a taxon’s [NCIT:C40098] seed morphology traits [TO:0000184] or fruit morphology traits [TO:0002629] that indicates the taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely disperse [OMIT: 0027297] seeds [PO:0009010] and fruit [PO:0009001] away from the parent plant.
Plant dispersal syndromes are generally assigned to species based on suites of diaspore characteristics associated with specific mechanisms of dispersal. Trait values are mostly given as the formal dispersal syndromes ending in ‘chory’, a suffix meaning ‘a specified method of plant dispersal’.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


dispersal_syndrome_anemochory Diaspore is dispersed by wind. (Synonyms, wind)
dispersal_syndrome_anthrochory Diaspore is dispersed by humans, either intentionally or unintentionally.
dispersal_syndrome_atelochory Diaspore dispersal is prevented. (Synonyms, antitelochory)
dispersal_syndrome_autochory Diaspore is dispersed by methods originating from the parent plant or diaspore.
dispersal_syndrome_ballistic Seeds are launched away from the plant by explosion as soon as the seed capsule opens.
dispersal_syndrome_barochory Diaspores are dispersed without assistance. (Synonyms, gravity, mobile, unassisted, passive)
dispersal_syndrome_chamaechory Diaspore is dispersed by being rolled along ground surface by wind.
dispersal_syndrome_endozoochory Diaspore is ingested by animals, either intentionally or accidentally, then transported before being deposited. (Synonyms, ingestion)
dispersal_syndrome_epizoochory Diaspore is dispersed by accidentally attaching itself to the outside of an animal vector. (Synonyms, ectozoochory, exozoochory)
dispersal_syndrome_hydrochory Diaspore is dispersed on the surface of water. (Synonyms, water)
dispersal_syndrome_myrmecochory Diaspores have elaiosomes (specialised nutritious appendages) that make them attractive for capture, transport and use by ants or related insects.
dispersal_syndrome_undefined Dispersal mechanism unknown. (Synonyms, unknown)
dispersal_syndrome_zoochory Diaspore is dispersed by animals, by an undescribed mechanism.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Diaspore dispersal agents











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030212




label


Diaspore dispersal agents




alternative label


dispersers




description



The taxa [NCIT:C40098] (biotic vectors) and abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that disperse [OMIT: 0027297] seeds [PO:0009010] and fruit [PO:0009001] away from a parent plant.
Dominant diaspore dispersal agents, including both biotic agents (specific taxa) or abiotic mechanisms responsible for dispersing seeds (or other dispersal units) away from the parent plant.




comments


Allowable terms for biotic dispersal agents include taxa at both the species-level and much broader groupings, reflecting both the different levels of resolution provided by researchers and whether a plant has specific versus broad dispersal agents. Abiotic dispersal mechanisms can likewise be quite general or specific, depending on data availability.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


dispersers_indigenous_people Indigenous people disperse the fruit through traditional practices.
dispersers_abiotic Fruits are dispersed by unspecified abiotic mechanisms.
dispersers_ants Ants are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_animals Animals are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_bats Bats are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_birds Birds are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_cassowaries Cassowaries, in contrast to smaller flying birds, are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_fish Fish are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_floods Floods are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_flying_vertebrates Flying birds and bats are important fruit dispersal agents.
dispersers_flying_foxes Flying foxes are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_garden_refuse Fruit are dispersed through garden refuse.
dispersers_insects Insects are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_invertebrates Invertebrates are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_mammals Mammals are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_mammals_domestic Domesticated ammals are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_non-flying_vertebrates Mammals and non-flying birds (i.e. cassowary, emu) are important fruit dispersal agents.
dispersers_passive There is no special dispersal agent.
dispersers_rain Rain is an important fruit dispersal agent; the diaspore is propelled by action of rain on plant structure or the wetting of the plant structure by rain or dew.
dispersers_rodents Rodents are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_vehicles Vehicles are an important dispersal agent, such as through mud on tyres.
dispersers_vertebrates Vertebrates are an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_wind Wind is an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_water Water is an important fruit dispersal agent.
dispersers_water_currents Water currents are an important fruit dispersal agent; the diaspore may be either floating or submerged in fresh/saltwater currents.

description



The environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] under which a taxon [NCIT:C40098] displays seed [PO:0009010] germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410], with trait values reflecting successional changes to the vegetation community.
The environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] under which a taxon’s seedlings can establish, with trait values reflecting successional changes to the vegetation community.




comments


The selection of trait values does not distinguish between the ability to establish in intermediate age versus mature vegetation, as this level of detail is rarely provided in datasets.

seedling_establishment_conditions_establish_post_disturbance Seedling establishment occurs following disturbances that increase light levels at the ground surface, but the type of disturbance is not documented.
seedling_establishment_conditions_establish_anytime Seedlings can establish immediately following a disturbance and in later years as vegetation ages, right thru to mature and over-mature vegetation
seedling_establishment_conditions_establish_intermediate_to_mature_vegetation Seedlings require some environmental characteristics not found in vegetation straight after fires to establish, for they cannot establish within the first season or two after fire but can establish in older vegetation (including mature to over-mature vegetation).

trait_0030217

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
section: Canopy light environment required for reproduction
text:
Canopy light environment required for reproduction











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030218




label


Canopy light environment required for reproduction




alternative label


reproductive_light_environment_index




description



A plant phenological [TO:0000933] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is an index [NCIT:C25390] that captures the level of photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864] required by plants for reproduction [GO:0000003].
The minimum light environment required by plants for reproduction, scaled from 0 to 8.




comments


0 indicates No direct light, extremely low levels of transmitted/reflected light, such as beneath dense fern or palm fronds close to ground level.; 0.5 indicates No direct light, very low levels of transmitted light; 1 indicates Rare or no exposure to direct light from lateral sources, and low levels of transmitted light.; 2 indicates Low lateral light and low-moderate transmitted light with <10% of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus low to moderate levels of transmitted light; 3 indicates Low-moderate lateral & moderate transmitted light, with <5% exposure of the focal crown to vertical direct light, and <15 % of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate transmitted light.; 4 indicates Moderate lateral light & moderate-high transmitted light, with 5 - 10% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus 2-20% exposure of inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate to high levels of transmitted light.; 5 indicates Moderate vertical light and moderate-high lateral light, with 5 - 20% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus one or both of, i. 10-40% exposure of 90-degree inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, ii. exposure to high levels of transmitted light; 6 indicates Moderate-High vertical and high lateral light, with 10-30% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, and lateral light exposure for > 40% of 90-degree inverted cone, 7 indicates High vertical and lateral light, with 30-80% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, or exposure to lateral sources of direct light for > 60 % of a 90-degree inverted cone encompassing the focal crown.; 8 indicates Full light exposure of crown, with > 80% of the vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light..

continuous variable




unit


{dimensionless}

The minimum light environment required by seedlings for establishment, scaled from 0 to 8.




comments


0 indicates No direct light, extremely low levels of transmitted/reflected light, such as beneath dense fern or palm fronds close to ground level.; 0.5 indicates No direct light, very low levels of transmitted light; 1 indicates Rare or no exposure to direct light from lateral sources, and low levels of transmitted light.; 2 indicates Low lateral light and low-moderate transmitted light with <10% of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus low to moderate levels of transmitted light; 3 indicates Low-moderate lateral & moderate transmitted light, with <5% exposure of the focal crown to vertical direct light, and <15 % of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate transmitted light.; 4 indicates Moderate lateral light & moderate-high transmitted light, with 5 - 10% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus 2-20% exposure of inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate to high levels of transmitted light.; 5 indicates Moderate vertical light and moderate-high lateral light, with 5 - 20% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus one or both of, i. 10-40% exposure of 90-degree inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, ii. exposure to high levels of transmitted light; 6 indicates Moderate-High vertical and high lateral light, with 10-30% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, and lateral light exposure for > 40% of 90-degree inverted cone, 7 indicates High vertical and lateral light, with 30-80% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, or exposure to lateral sources of direct light for > 60 % of a 90-degree inverted cone encompassing the focal crown.; 8 indicates Full light exposure of crown, with > 80% of the vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light..

text:
Serotiny











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030412




label


Serotiny




alternative label


serotiny




description



A fire response trait which indicates whether a fruit [PO:0009001] or cone [strobilus; PO:0025083] remains closed in the canopy [ENVO:01001242] after maturation [TO:0002661], with the seed [PO:0009010] only being released [NCIT:C42882] after a specific [NCIT:C38024] environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203], usually an environmental cue associated with a fire [ENVO:01000786], but possibly also drought or extreme heat.
Categorical variable describing whether a fruit or cone remains closed in the plant canopy after maturation until an environmental cue, usually a fire, but possibly also drought or extreme heat, triggers it to release its seeds.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


serotiny_not_serotinous Plant does not display serotiny.
serotiny_serotinous Plant serotinous, level not specified.
serotiny_serotiny_low Plant displays a weak level of serotiny, indicating it releases most of its seeds gradually, with only a small proportion of the seeds retained as a canopy seedbank until an environmental cue triggers the release of the entire seedbank.
serotiny_serotiny_moderate Plant displays a moderate level of serotiny, indicating it releases some of its seeds gradually, with the remainder retained as a canopy seedbank until an environmental cue triggers the release of the entire seedbank.
serotiny_serotiny_high Plant displays a strong level of serotiny, indicating all seeds are retained as a canopy seedbank until an environmental cue triggers their release.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Seedbank longevity class











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030413




label


Seedbank longevity class




alternative label


seedbank_longevity_class




description



A seedbank’s [MESH:D000068098] longevity [EnvThes:22228], expressed as a categorical variable [STATO:0000252], where seedbank longevity is the time interval (duration [PATO:0001309]) a mature [PATO:0001701] seed [PO:0009010] remains in the seedbank, viable [PATO_0000169] and able to germinate [GO:0009845].
Categorical groupings indicating the length of time (duration) a mature seed remains in the seedbank, viable and able to germinate.




comments


Seedbank longevity classes are a feature of a population (sample) of seeds, not an individual seed. Also see the traits seedbank_longevity (numeric trait), seed_dormancy_class and the trait seed_recruitment_timing.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


seedbank_longevity_class_transient Seed that survives in the seedbank until its first annual germination season, but not until its second annual germination season. Some transient seeds will germinate within weeks to months, while others may remain in the seedbank for slightly over a year, depending on how the annual recruitment season aligns with seed maturation. Transient seeds are non-dormant, remaining in the seedbank until environmental conditions are appropriate for germination.
seedbank_longevity_class_persistent Seed that survives in the seedbank until at least its second germination season.
seedbank_longevity_class_short_persistent Seed that persists in the seedbank for approximately 1 to 5 years, although the time interval varies by study.
seedbank_longevity_class_long_persistent Seed that persists in the seedbank for more than 5 years, although the time interval varies by study.
seedbank_longevity_class_widely_dispersed Seed longevity not important, as seeds are widely dispersed and always available for germination.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Seedbank longevity











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030414




label


Seedbank longevity




alternative label


seedbank_longevity




description



The half-life of the seedbank [MESH:D000068098], with is the time interval (duration [PATO:0001309]) from when seeds [PO:0009010] in a seedbank mature [PATO:0001701] until more than half the seeds in a seedbank are no longer able to germinate [GO:0009845].
The half-life of the seedbank, which is the length of time (duration) from when seeds in a seedbank mature until more than half the seeds in a seedbank are no longer able to germinate.




comments


Seedbank longevity can only be measured on a population (sample) of seeds, not on an individual seed. Also see the traits seedbank_longevity_class, seed_dormancy_class and seed_recruitment_timing.

text:
Seed germination treatment











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030416




label


Seed germination treatment




alternative label


seed_germination_treatment




description



The treatment [EFO:0000727] or experimental conditions [XCO:0000000] required for a high [NCIT:C25227] proportion [PATO:0001470] of seeds [PO:0009010] to germinate [GO:0009845] .
Treatment required for seed to display high germination rates. The data included in AusTraits are mostly from seed banks that have recorded the protocols they use to encourage seeds to germinate. The treatments may therefore be only loosely connected to the cues required for a species’ to break dormancy.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


seed_germination_treatment_after_ripening Seed germinates more readily after a period of warm, dry storage.
seed_germination_treatment_chemical_treatment Seed germinates more readily after a chemical treatment.
seed_germination_treatment_cold Seed germinates more readily after cold treatment.
seed_germination_treatment_dark Seed germinates more readily after being stored in the dark.
seed_germination_treatment_heat Seed germinates more readily after being heated.
seed_germination_treatment_heat_lethal Seed is heat sensitive. (A fire response, more than a treatment to break dormancy.)
seed_germination_treatment_heat+smoke Seed germinates more readily after a treatment that merges heat and smoke.
seed_germination_treatment_imbibe_hot Seed germinates more readily after being soaked in hot water; water temperature usually between 70 deg C to just below boiling.
seed_germination_treatment_leaching Seed germinates more readily after leaching out certain chemicals.
seed_germination_treatment_light Seed germinates more readily after light exposure.
seed_germination_treatment_mycorrhizae Seed germinates more readily if infected by a mycorrhizal symbiont.
seed_germination_treatment_none No treatment required for seed to display high germination rates.
seed_germination_treatment_rain Seed germinates more readily after rain.
seed_germination_treatment_scarify Seed coat is removed, nicked, or otherwise punctured to increase germination.
seed_germination_treatment_smoke Seed germinates more readily after being subjected to a smoke treatment; includes smoked water.
seed_germination_treatment_stratification Seed germinates more readily after being stored in moist conditions; not specified if the treatment was cold stratification or warm stratification.
seed_germination_treatment_stratification_cold Seed germinates more readily after a period of cold, wet storage.
seed_germination_treatment_stratification_warm Seed germinates more readily after a period of warm, wet storage.

Vegetative reproduction ability











Property


Value







URI

label


Vegetative reproduction ability

vegetative_reproduction_ability




description



A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is the ability [NCIT:C78209] of individual [EFO:0000542] plants to reproduce [GO:0000003] through asexual reproduction [GO:0019954] (vegetative reproduction).
A binary trait, indicating whether a plant taxon is able to reproduce and spread through the growth and division of vegetative material.




comments


For plants able to reproduce vegetatively, more detailed information about the mechanisms and structures that allow clonal spread is provided in the trait clonal_spread_mechanism. The trait dispersal_unit captures information on plants that never produce by seed.

vegetative_reproduction_ability_vegetative Plant taxa that can regenerate and spread through the growth and division of vegetative material, not just from seed; examples include runners, rhizomes, and bulbs.
vegetative_reproduction_ability_vegetative_obligate Plant taxa that never (or very rarely) regenerate from seed, instead regenerating and spreading entirely through the growth and division of vegetative material.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Clonal spread mechanism











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030511




label


Clonal spread mechanism




alternative label


clonal_spread_mechanism




description



A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the mechanism [NCIT:C25343] plants use for clonal growth [EnvThes:21032] (asexual reproduction [GO:0019954]) or for regeneration [GO:0031099] after a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373]
Mechanisms and structures (tissues, organs, or other structures) a plant uses to spread vegetatively, including the production of clones.




comments


See vegetative_reproduction_ability for a binary description of whether a plant can spread vegetatively. There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: storage_organ indicates the plant structures where a plant stores excess carbohydrates; these organs may or may not facilitate clonal spread; bud_bank_location indicates the location of meristematic tissue (buds) that allow regeneration following a disturbance or after an annual unfavourable season.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


clonal_spread_mechanism_aboveground_clonal Vegetative buds or plant fragments that can disperse and produce new plants (including axillary buds, bulbils and turions).
clonal_spread_mechanism_adventitious_roots Adventitious roots can form at nodes on the main roots or aboveground from nodes on stems.
clonal_spread_mechanism_bulb Below ground storage organ derived from stem (and sometimes leaf) tissue, that divides into new individuals.
clonal_spread_mechanism_belowground_clonal Plants use an unspecified underground organ for clonal spread.
clonal_spread_mechanism_corm Below ground organ derived from stem tissue that can function either for vegetative spread or to regenerate following a disturbance.
clonal_spread_mechanism_rhizome Plant has an underground stem that has stem buds and forms adventitious roots at nodes; this stem may be woody or non-woody. Rhizomes are both a mechanism for vegetative spread and a strategy to survive fire.
clonal_spread_mechanism_root_buds Root buds that produce vertical suckers.
clonal_spread_mechanism_root_tuber A swollen root that functions as a storage organ and has buds that allow clonal growth.
clonal_spread_mechanism_stem_tuber A swollen underground stem that functions as a storage organ and has buds that allow clonal growth.
clonal_spread_mechanism_stolon Plants having horizontal branches (stems) from the base of the plant that produce new plants from buds at its tip or nodes.
clonal_spread_mechanism_viviparous Plant produces clonal offspring that grow while still attached to the parent plant.
clonal_spread_mechanism_non_clonal Plant does not display clonal growth.

trait_0030511

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Storage organ











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030512




label


Storage organ




alternative label


storage_organ




description



A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the type [NCIT:C25284] of storage organ [EFO:0000997] a plant has, where a storage organ is a plant part (organ [PO:0009008], tissue [PO:0009007], or other plant structure [PO:0009011]) whose function [NCIT:C25518] is carbohydrate [CHEBI:16646] (energy [PATO:0001021]) storage.
Plant structures (tissues, organs, or other structures) where a plant stores excess carbohydrates (energy). The stored energy may be used for future growth, including clonal spread and regrowth following an annual unfavourable season, or for regrowth following a disturbance event (including post-fire regeneration or another disturbance event that causes leaf loss). Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.




comments


There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: clonal_spread_mechanism indicates mechanisms and structures a plant actually uses for vegetative spread; not all energy storage organs also allow vegetative spread; bud_bank_location indicates the location of meristematic tissue (buds) that allow regeneration following a disturbance or after an annual unfavourable season. See Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 (doi.org/10.1111/nph.14982) for detailed descriptions of recolonization ability and level of fire protection provided by each regeneration strategy.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


storage_organ_bulb Below ground storage organ derived from stem and usually leaf tissue.
storage_organ_corm Below ground storage organ that is a short, rounded, vertical, fleshy, underground stem.
storage_organ_caudex Swollen stem that usually functions in water storage, although the term can also apply to below ground structures or to swollen roots.
storage_organ_fleshy_underground_organ Plants that use fleshy, generally underground organs (swellings) to regenerate, but the type of organ is not specified; examples include corms, tubers, bulbs, and caudex.
storage_organ_lignotuber Swollen woody structures are located at the transition between the stem base and root crown of woody shrubs, mallees and small trees, and are formed from stem tissues. Buds are located over the entire structure. No colonisation ability.
storage_organ_pseudobulb An above ground storage organ present in many terrestrial and epiphytic orchids created throough the thickening of the stem between leaf nodes.
storage_organ_rhizome A type of continually growing or creeping underground stem, but it is not specified if the rhizome is woody or non-woody.
storage_organ_rhizome_woody A type of continually growing or creeping woody underground stem.
storage_organ_rhizome_fleshy A type of continually growing or creeping fleshy, non-woody underground stem.
storage_organ_rhizome_fibrous A type of continually growing or creeping fibrous, non-woody underground stem.
storage_organ_root_tuber A swollen root the stores nutrients, carbohydrates and water. (Synonym, taproot tuber)
storage_organ_stem_tuber A swollen underground stem that stores nutrients, carbohydrates and water.
storage_organ_storage_organ Plant has a storage organ, but the type is unknown.
storage_organ_tuber A swollen underground organ that stores nutrients, carbohydrates and water, where it is not specified if the tuber develops from root or stem tissue.
storage_organ_no_storage_organ No storage organ present

trait_0030512

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Bud bank location











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030513




label


Bud bank location




alternative label


bud_bank_location




description



The position [PATO:0000140] and distribution [PATO:0000060] of vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) on a plant [PO:0000003]. These may be buds that allow a plant to regrow following an unfavourable season or buds that survive [EnvThes:21064] a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373] such as a fire, cyclone or drought. In particular, they may be meristematic tissue that survives a fire [ENVO:01000786] and allows the plant to resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following the fire.
The location of buds (meristematic tissue) on a plant that allows it to resprout following a fire, annual unfavourable season, or other disturbance event, such as a drought or cyclone. Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.




comments


There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: clonal_spread_mechanism indicates mechanisms and structures a plant actually uses for vegetative spread; not all energy storage organs also allow vegetative spread; storage_organ indicates the plant structures where a plant stores excess carbohydrates. See Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 (doi.org/10.1111/nph.14982) for detailed descriptions of recolonization ability and level of fire protection provided by each regeneration strategy. If specific bud banks only survive some types of disturbance, the disturbance should be specified as a context property.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


bud_bank_location_apical_buds Plants resprout from above-ground apical meristems. Also termed a caudex. Term refers to palm-like plants with aerial buds that resprout, including grass trees, palms, tree ferns, and pandanus. (Synonym, aerial apical sprouter)
bud_bank_location_basal_buds Plants resprout from its base, with buds originating from stem tissue (e.g. lignotuber) and root tissue (root crown) not distinguished between. Most buds designated as being basal are likely to be resprouts from a lignotuber, but this trait value is used if the dataset reported basal buds rather than basal stem buds or lignotuber.
bud_bank_location_basal_stem_buds Plants resprout from the base of the stem. Australian plants with basal stem buds usually have a lignotuber, documented in the trait storage_organ. (Synonym, rootstock, lignotuberous resprouter)
bud_bank_location_epicormic_buds Plants resprout from the stem or trunk.
bud_bank_location_fleshy_underground_organ Plants resprouts from buds on a fleshy underground organ that is a taproot tuber, bulb, corm, stem tuber, root tuber, or belowground caudex. (Synonym, geophyte)
bud_bank_location_root_crown Plants resprout from the root crown, the root tissue at the root-stem transition.
bud_bank_location_bud-bearing_root Root buds produce vertical suckers (from root crown) or adventitious roots. (Synonyms, root-suckering resprouter; adventitious buds)
bud_bank_location_rhizome Plants resprout from buds on a rhizome, where it is not specified if the rhizome is woody or non-woody.
bud_bank_location_rhizome_woody Plants resprout from buds on a woody rhizome.
bud_bank_location_rhizome_non_woody Plants resprout from buds on a fleshy rhizome, rhizophore, or fibrous rhizome.
bud_bank_location_stem_buds Plants resprout from stem buds; this trait value is separate to epicormic buds. (Synonyms, aerial axillary resprouter)
bud_bank_location_stem_tuber Plants resprout from buds on a stem tuber.
bud_bank_location_stolon Horizontal branches (stems) resprout from the base of the plant.
bud_bank_location_underground_buds Plants that resprout from underground organ, but the type of organ isn’t specified.
bud_bank_location_none Plants lack regenerative buds.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Post-fire resprouting capacity











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030610




label


Post-fire resprouting capacity




alternative label


resprouting_capacity




description



A fire response trait which indicates whether mature [PATO:0001701] plants [PO:0000003] from a taxon [NCIT:C40098] or population [PCO:0000001] are killed or have vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] that causes 100% leaf scorch, with fire severity index [EnvThes:22120] an important contextual variable.
Trait indicating whether mature individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to fire that causes 100% leaf scorch. Species where at least 70% of plants resprout are designated resprouters, while those where fewer than 30% of plants resprout are designated as fire killed. Species with an intermediate response have a mixed fire response, and are coded as fire_killed resprouts.




comments


This trait is narrowly applicable only to taxa that experience fire; see the trait fire_exposure_level for trait values related to species whose strategy is to avoid fire.

resprouting_capacity_partial_resprouting Between 30-70% of plants resprout following a fire with 100% leaf scorch.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Post-fire to pre-fire stem ratio











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030614




label


Post-fire to pre-fire stem ratio




alternative label


resprouting_capacity_stem_ratio




description



A fire response trait which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of stems [PO:0009047] per individual [EFO:0000542] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] to the count of stems per individual before the fire, recorded for taxa that have multiple stems emerging from the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground].
Ratio of stem count post-fire to basal stem count (e.g. grass tillers) pre-fire at an individual or population level. This trait is appropriate to score for plants that have many stems from the base (shrubs, herbs, graminoids) where the number of stems is censused both before and after the fire. It is a continuous measure of resprouting strength conditioned on initial size.




comments


This trait will usually be recorded in natural or experimental systems subjected to a controlled burn, where stem counts can be censused both before and after a fire. However, it is appropriate to include data for any plants subjected to fire where the dead stems can still be counted post-fire.

section: Plant vegetative response to disturbances other than fire
text:
Plant vegetative response to disturbances other than fire











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030615




label


Plant vegetative response to disturbances other than fire




alternative label


resprouting_capacity_non_fire_disturbance




description



A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is the ability [NCIT:C78209] of individual [EFO:0000542] plants to regenerate [GO:0031099] vegetatively (resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout]) from meristematic tissue [PO:0006079], buds [PO:0000055]) after a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373] other than a fire [ENVO:01000786] that causes 100% defoliation.
A plant’s ability to regenerate vegetatively (resprout) from a disturbance other than fire that causes 100% defoliation.




comments


This trait explicitly refers to a plant’s vegetative regeneration ability following a disturbance event other than fire. See other resprouting_capacity traits, bud_bank_location, and clonal_spread_mechanism for other information about a plant’s ability to resprout. Just as post-fire resprouting capacity is documented in individuals that have suffered 100% leaf scorch, this trait should be scored only on individuals that have suffered 100% leaf loss. If a different leaf loss percentage is used, this needs to be documented as a context property.

categorical variable




has narrower


resprouting_capacity_non_fire_disturbance_resprouts_non_fire_disturbance Plants that are known to be fire-killed, but have the ability to resprout following a disturbance other than fire that causes 100% leaf loss.
resprouting_capacity_non_fire_disturbance_resprouts_after_cyclone Plants are able to resprout following 100% leaf loss in a cyclone.
resprouting_capacity_non_fire_disturbance_resprouts_after_drought Plants are able to resprout following 100% leaf loss during a drought.

Fire exposure level











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030651




label


Fire exposure level




alternative label


fire_exposure_level




description



A fire response trait indicating small-scale variation in plant [PO:0000003] habitat [ENVO:01000739] or growing season that protects the plant’s shoot systems [PO:0009006] or root system [PO:0025025] from exposure [NCIT:C17941] to fire [ENVO:01000786] or being damaged (scorched) by fire, when a fire occurs nearby.
Trait indicating habitat (or microhabitat) variation that protects the shoot or root system of some taxa from being exposed to fire and scorched by the fire, even when a fire burns nearby.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


fire_exposure_level_aquatic_taxon Plants rarely or never experience fires because they are aquatic.
fire_exposure_level_fire_avoidance_among_rocks Plants rarely experience fires because their habitat is restricted to rocky outcrops or rock pavement.
fire_exposure_level_fire_avoidance_near_water Plants rarely or never experience fires because their habitat is close to a body of water.
fire_exposure_level_fire_avoidance_in_swamp Plants rarely experience fires because their habitat is usually saturated, but populations can be catastrophically impacted during severe droughts when the swamps dry out.
fire_exposure_level_seasonal_fire_avoidance Plants avoid fire by only have above-ground parts during seasons when fire is rare or absent, but populations can be catastrophically impacted if fire occurs during an atypical season.

Post-fire recruitment











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030652




label


Post-fire recruitment




alternative label


post_fire_recruitment




description



A fire response trait which is the magnitude [NCIT:C49158] of seed [PO:0009010] germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410] after a fire [ENVO:01000786].
A trait indicating the magnitude of seed germination and seedling establishment following a fire.




comments


This trait does not suggest what mechanism(s) is triggering post-fire recruitment, but only that a post-fire response is (or is not) observed. There are several fire-related context properties that should be documented whenever possible, including fire severity (most important), fire season, and fire frequency. In addition, the time from fire to recruitment will vary greatly across systems, and, when available, a basic habitat description should be documented as a location property.

categorical variable

post_fire_recruitment_post_fire_recruitment Plants that germinate post-fire.
post_fire_recruitment_post_fire_recruitment_absent Plants that do not show increased seeding following fire.

description



A fire response trait which is a taxon’s [NCIT:C40098] flowering [PO:0007016] response [NCIT:C25755] to fire [ENVO:01000786], indicating if the magnitude [NCIT_C49158] of flowers [PO:0009046] increases, decreases or remains unchanged following a fire.
Indication of whether the magnitude of flowers produced by a taxon increases, decreases or remains unchanged following a fire.




comments


This trait does not suggest what mechanism(s) is triggering post-fire flowering, but only that a post-fire response is (or is not) observed. There are several fire-related context properties that should be documented whenever possible, including fire severity (most important), fire season, and fire frequency. In addition, the time from fire to flowering will vary greatly across systems, and, when available, a basic habitat description should be documented as a location property.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


post_fire_flowering_fire_dependent_flowering Plants predominantly flower after a fire, usually within the first 1-4 growing seasons following the fire.
post_fire_flowering_fire_enhanced_flowering Flowering is enhanced after a fire, with plants flowering more prolifically for the first 1-4 growing seasons following the fire.
post_fire_flowering_fire_independent_flowering Flowering is independent of fire, with the magnitude of flowers produced by plants unchanged following a fire.
post_fire_flowering_fire_suppressed_flowering Flowering is suppressed or absent after a fire, with plants producing fewer flowers for at least the first 1-4 growing seasons following the fire.

Property

Time from fire to first flowering




alternative label


fire_time_from_fire_to_flowering




description



A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until one individual [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population [PCO:0000001] reaches whole plant flowering stage [PO_0007016].
The time interval from a fire until the first individual in a population begins flowering.




comments


This trait can include data that documents the time from a fire until either a resprouter or a fire-killed species first begins flowering, as both have important regeneration and conservation implications. Whenever available, a context property should be added to indicate if data are scoring the time from seed germination or post-fire resprouting to the onset of flowering.

https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030658




label


Time from fire to fruiting




alternative label


fire_time_from_fire_to_fruiting




description



A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until one individual [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population [PCO:0000001] produces mature [PATO:0001701] fruit [PO:0009001].
The time interval from a fire until the first individual in a population produces a mature fruit with viable propagules.




comments


This trait can include data that documents the time from a fire until either a resprouter or a fire-killed species first begins producing mature fruit, as both have important regeneration and conservation implications. Whenever available, a context property should be added to indicate if data are scoring the time from seed germination or post-fire resprouting to the onset of fruiting.

text:
Fuel bed bulk density











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030710




label


Fuel bed bulk density




alternative label


fire_fuel_bed_bulk_density




description



Fuel bed bulk density (volume density [PATO:0001353]), which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the mass [PATO:0000125] of the fuel bed divided by the fuel bed volume [PATO:0000918]; the term fuel bed refers to the accumulated plant litter [ENVO:01000628] on the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground], as this is the fuel [CHEBI:33292] that is burnt in a ground fire [ENVO:01000786].
The density of the fuel bed, the plant litter accumulated on the ground. It is calculated as the ratio of the mass of the fuel bed to the fuel bed volume. This trait should be measured on plant litter from a single taxon.




comments


In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon and fuel bed will instead be a ‘community level’ trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document fuel bed bulk density in experimental situations.

description



A fire response trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] of the portion of fire [ENVO:01000786]-induced combustion [NCIT:C157201] process from the time when a flame [ENVO:01000789] is no longer visible until smoulder combustion ends.
Smoulder duration for a single leaf, which is the time from the end of the last visible flame until the glowing phase dies out.




comments


In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a ‘community level’ trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document rates of fire spread in experimental situations.

text:
Plant resource requirements and tolerance











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030810




label


Plant resource requirements and tolerance




alternative label


plant_type_by_resource_use




description



An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on the environmental conditions in which they survive and thrive, including their tolerance of, sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to, and requirement [NCIT:C25652] for certain resource availabilities [EnvThes:21497], including water [CHEBI:15377] availability and soil [ENVO:00001998] nutrient [CHEBI:33284] content and salinity [PATO:0085001].
Classification scheme of plant resource requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa based on their water, soil nutrient, and soil salinity requirements and tolerances.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


plant_type_by_resource_use_hydrohalophyte Tidal swamp or ‘mangrove’ and coastal lagoon elements and temperate-zone salt-marsh taxa are classed together.
plant_type_by_resource_use_phreatophyte Deep-rooted plants<U+2014>usually trees<U+2014>obtaining water from a deep underground source that may or may not be saline.
plant_type_by_resource_use_psammophile Sand-loving plants commonly found in littoral strand or inland sandfields.
plant_type_by_resource_use_weedy This inexact term is meant to indicate a high degree of adaptability to sites, and proven tendency toward aggressive colonization of either dry or wet sites, or rarely, both. In general, weeds invade and colonize highly disturbed sites or areas.
plant_type_by_resource_use_xerohalophyte Plants adapted to inland salt desert and saline habitats.
plant_type_by_resource_use_xerophyte Drought-tolerant and drought-adapted plants.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Plant flood regime response











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030811




label


Plant flood regime response




alternative label


plant_flood_regime_classification




description



An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on the depth [PATO:0001595], duration [PATO:0001309] and frequency [PATO:0000044] of inundation [SWEET:phenSystem/Inundation] a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate. It incorporates their ability to tolerate or respond to fluctuations in flooding [ENVO:01000710] and drying, including growth [GO:0040007] and seed germination [GO:0009845] responses.
Classification scheme of plant flood regime requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa into seven groups based on their germination and growth responses to flood regimes.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


plant_flood_regime_classification_terrestrial_dry Species which germinate, grow and reproduce where there is no surface water and the water table is below the soil surface. (Dry species; Tdr)
plant_flood_regime_classification_terrestrial_damp Species which germinate, grow and reproduce on saturated soil. (Damp species; Tda)
plant_flood_regime_classification_amphibious_fluctuation_tolerators_emergent Species which germinate in damp or flooded conditions, which tolerate variation in water level, and which grow with their basal portions under water and reproduce out of water. (Emergent species; ATe)
plant_flood_regime_classification_amphibious_fluctuation_tolerators_low Species which germinate in damp or flooded conditions, which tolerate variation in water level, which are low-growing and tolerate complete submersion when water-levels rise. (Low-growing species; ATl)
plant_flood_regime_classification_amphibious_fluctuation_responders_plastic Species which germinate in flooded conditions, grow in both flooded and damp conditions, reproduce above the surface of the water, and which have morphological plasticity (e.g. heterophylly) in response to water-level variation. (Morphologically plastic species; ARp)
plant_flood_regime_classification_amphibious_fluctuation_responders_floating Species which germinate in flooded conditions, grow in both flooded and damp conditions, reproduce above the surface of the water, and which have floating leaves when inundated. (Species with floating leaves; ARf)
plant_flood_regime_classification_amphibious Species which germinate in damp or flooded conditions and can grow in or our of water.
plant_flood_regime_classification_submerged Species which germinate, grow and reproduce underwater. (S

Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030812




label


Plant water-logging tolerance




alternative label


plant_tolerance_water_logged_soils




description



An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] that a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate water-logged soils, an indication of a plant’s sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to flood [ENVO:01000710] conditions. Soil [ENVO:00001998] is considered water-logged if it is saturated [NCIT:C61427] with water [CHEBI:15377], limiting the plant root’s [PO:0009005] ability to respire [GO:0045333] due to a lack of soil oxygen [CHEBI:15379].
Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate water-logged soils.




comments






value type


categorical variable




has narrower


plant_tolerance_water_logged_soils_not_applicable Taxa is not typically confronted with waterlogging and its response is unknown.
plant_tolerance_water_logged_soils_less_than_1_month Taxa able to tolerate less than 1 month of waterlogging.
plant_tolerance_water_logged_soils_1-6_months Taxa able to tolerate 1-6 months of waterlogging.
plant_tolerance_water_logged_soils_greater_than_6_months Taxa able to tolerate more than 6 months of waterlogging.
plant_tolerance_water_logged_soils_aquatic Taxa truly aquatic and able to be permanently inundated.

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Plant salt tolerance strategy











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030816




label


Plant salt tolerance strategy




alternative label


plant_tolerance_salt




description



An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on their salinity [PATO:0085001] tolerance [TO:0006001], reflecting the duration [PATO:0001309] and concentration [PATO:0000033] of salt [CHEBI:24866] exposure that a plant is able to tolerate.
Classification scheme of plant salt-tolerance categories, categorising taxa based on their tolerance of or sensitivity to salty soils, salt spray, or salt water.




comments


The trait soil_salinity_tolerance documents actual soil salinity levels taxa can tolerate. The trait plant_type_by_resource_use has some overlapping values, but focuses on terms to describe a plant’s overall resource tolerances/requirements, while this trait focuses on terms associated with salinity tolerances/requirements. The trait plant_tolerance_soil_salinity offers numeric soil salinity levels a taxon can tolerate.




value type


categorical variable




has narrower


plant_tolerance_salt_glycophyte Plants that cannot survive even one tenth the salt concentration found in seawater.
plant_tolerance_salt_halophyte Plants that complete their life cycle in a salty environment; many survive in seawater or even higher concentrations of salt.
plant_tolerance_salt_halophyte_moderate Plant that is moderately tolerant of soil salinity/sodicity.
plant_tolerance_salt_hydrohalophyte Tidal swamp or ‘mangrove’ and coastal lagoon elements and temperate-zone salt-marsh taxa are classed together.
plant_tolerance_salt_salt_spray_tolerant Plant that is tolerant of salt spray (typically inhabiting near-coastal environments).
plant_tolerance_salt_salinity_tolerance_undefined Plant’s ability to tolerate salt is unknown.
plant_tolerance_salt_xerohalophyte Plants adapted to inland salt desert and saline habitats.

Plant calcium sensitivity











Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/trait_0030817




label


Plant calcium sensitivity




alternative label


plant_tolerance_calcicole




description



An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is a plant’s [PO:0000003] calcium sensitivity [TO:0000006], corresponding to its sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to high soil [ENVO:00001998] pH [NCIT:C45997].
Classification scheme of plant soil calcium tolerance, corresponding to its sensitivity to high soil pH. Plants are categorised as either calcifuge (intolerant of basic soils) or calcicole (tolerant of basic soils, such as calcareous sands and limestone derived soils).

text:
Root system morphology

type_i










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_i




label


type_i




description


The primary root is fibrous or fleshy and is relatively long; mesophytic.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_i








type_ii










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_ii




label


type_ii




description


The primary root is relatively short and is fibrous. Roots are well branched in a dry habitat but branch little in one that is wet.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_ii








type_iii










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_iii




label


type_iii




description


The primary root is usually long and fibrous. The first order lateral roots are well branched and are usually short; they are rather evenly distributed along the primary root; xerophytic.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_iii








type_iv










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_iv




label


type_iv




description


The primary root is usually long and slender like that of Type II. The first order lateral roots are well branched. Those closest to the surface of the ground, or not far below, are relatively long; xerophytic and mesophytic.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_iv








type_v










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_v




label


type_v




description


The primary root is divided-forked or branched-and fibrous, and with few first order lateral roots, or, in age, apparently with none; xerophytic.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_v








type_vi










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_vi




label


type_vi




description


The primary root is usually as in Type V. The first order lateral roots are mostly on the upper portion of the primary root and are thus relatively superficial; xerophytic or in well aerated sandy soil where the rainfall is not light.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_vi








type_vii










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_vii




label


type_vii




description


Adventitious roots that are in one group and arise on a short horizontal, or vertical, axis of the shoot. They are fibrous or fleshly; mesophytic and hydrophytic.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_vii








type_viii










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_viii




label


type_viii




description


Adventitious roots that are in one group and are fibrous and fleshy, or fibrous and thick. The fibrous adventitious roots are absorbing-anchoring roots and are usually with laterals to the second order; meophytic.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_viii








type_ix










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/root_system_classification_type_ix




label


type_ix




description


Adventitious roots that arise on the aerial stem and branches of some herbaceous taxa, shrubs, and trees; on creepers, vines, and runners; and on subterranean rhizomes and stolons.




has broader


Root system morphology




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


root_system_classification_type_ix

title: The AusTraits Plant Dictionary (APD) Ontology
text:
Plant growth form

herb










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_herb




label


herb




description


A seed-bearing plant which does not have a woody above-ground stem; when available this term has been divided into more detailed terms. (Synonyms, forb)




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_herb








subshrub










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_subshrub




label


subshrub




description


A plant that is only woody at the base, with the remainder of the stems regenerating yearly. This term is not meant to encompass short-lived plants that are only borderline woody. (Synonyms, suffrutescent)




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_subshrub








shrub










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_shrub




label


shrub




description


A woody plant that is distinguished by NOT being a tree, due to one of more of the following characteristics, 1) they are less than 8 metres in height; 2) if a plant community includes trees, the shrubs are shorter than the surrounding trees and not part of the canopy; 3) in comparison to trees, the leaves are more distributed along the entire trunk; 4) the plant has multiple relatively narrow stems arising at or near ground level. The definition of shrub is complex, as there are many single-stemmed shrubs within Australia and many taxa that are described in the taxonomic literature as a shrub or small tree.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_shrub








mallee










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_mallee




label


mallee




description


Refers to Eucalyptus species which are small trees that form a large lignotuber. They have multiple stems arising at or near ground level and regenerate from the lignotuber following fire.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_mallee








tree










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_tree




label


tree




description


A tall, woody, perennial plant, usually with a single main trunk, and its leaves predominantly elevated above the ground surface.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_tree








graminoid










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_graminoid




label


graminoid




description


Herbaceous plant with a grass-like morphology that is within the order Poales. Taxa both with and without a tussock form are mapped to this term. This term is most frequently applied to three large monocot families, Poaceae, Cyperaceae, and Juncaceae, but the term could apply to other taxa within Poales with a grass-like morphology, including narrow, linear leaves and non-showy flowers, including Restionaceae, Centrolepidaceae, Anarthriaceae, and Ecdeiocoleaceae. Taxa outside Poales with a grass-like morphology should be designated as herbs and also have the term tufted mapped to the trait stem_growth_habit.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_graminoid








tussock










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_tussock




label


tussock




description


A subcategory of graminoid, which is a plant where many shoots from the basal meristem form prominent tufts.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme

identifier


plant_growth_form_tussock

Property


Value

A subcategory of graminoid, indicating a plant which explicitly lacks a tussock morphology, with the leaves not growing in tufts.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_graminoid_not_tussock








hummock










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_hummock




label

description


Plant that grows as a dense mound up to 1 metre in height. The term generally applies only to species within the genera Triodia that form such mounds and these are considered a distinctive and uniquely Australian growth form.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_hummock








basal_large










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_basal_large




label

description


A plant whose leaves form a distinctly large basal tuft or rosette, including large acaulescent monocots and cycads.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier

geophyte










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_geophyte




label

description


Subcategory of herb, specifically referring to plants that survive the winter/dry season as an organ (rhizome, bulb, corm, or tuber) buried in dry soil, with all leaves dying back each year.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_geophyte








palmoid










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_palmoid




label

description


Plant that bears a rosette-like canopy of typically large, often compound leaves atop a usually thick (pachycaulous), columnar, unbranched or little-branched stem. Palms, tree ferns, trunked cycads, trunked grass-trees, and Pandanus are mapped to this term. (Synonyms, rosette-tree, palm, grass-tree)




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_palmoid








climber










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_climber




label


climber




description


Plant that climbs up another plant’s stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. Term used only if datasets do not specify if a climbing plant is herbaceous (a vine) or woody (a liana).




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme

identifier


plant_growth_form_climber

Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_climber_herbaceous




label

description


Herbaceous plant that climbs up another plant’s stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with vine. Types of climbers (scrambling, twining) are captured under the trait plant_climbing_mechanism. (Synonyms, vine)




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_climber_herbaceous








climber_woody










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_climber_woody




label


climber_woody




description


Woody or thick-stemmed (>2 cm) plant that climbs up another plant’s stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with liana. Woody climbers generally use hooks, tendrils, and/or adventitious roots to climb; the climbing mechanisms used by a taxon are captured under the trait plant_climbing_mechanism. (Synonyms, liana)




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_climber_woody








fern










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_fern




label


fern

A taxonomic grouping; ferns are vascular plants that reproduce via spores.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme


https://w3id.org/APD/traits




identifier


plant_growth_form_fern








lycophyte










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/plant_growth_form_lycophyte




label

description


A taxonomic grouping that includes quillworts, clubmosses, and selaginella.




has broader


Plant growth form




is in scheme

identifier

has broader

Annual plants whose shoot and root systems die completely at the end of flowering and seed production, such that they survive the unfavourable cold or dry season in the form of seeds.

Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/parasitic_hemiparasitic

hemiparasitic




description


Plant that is photosynthetic but augments its energy, mineral nutrition, and /or water supply through parasitism. This trait value does not distinguish between obligate hemiparasites, plants which require a host for at least part of their life cycle, and facultative hemiparasites, plants which can grow and reproduce without a host.

Plant parasitism status

Seedbank longevity class

transient










Property


Value







URI


https://w3id.org/APD/traits/seedbank_longevity_class_transient




label


transient




description


Seed that survives in the seedbank until its first annual germination season, but not until its second annual germination season. Some transient seeds will germinate within weeks to months, while others may remain in the seedbank for slightly over a year, depending on how the annual recruitment season aligns with seed maturation. Transient seeds are non-dormant, remaining in the seedbank until environmental conditions are appropriate for germination.

identifier

Plants resprout from its base, with buds originating from stem tissue (e.g. lignotuber) and root tissue (root crown) not distinguished between. Most buds designated as being basal are likely to be resprouts from a lignotuber, but this trait value is used if the dataset reported basal buds rather than basal stem buds or lignotuber.
